subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.
If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg.
Too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

goal_quotes: Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.

Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara. But this is not carbonara.
meta_summary.procedure: The process involves preparing a dish similar to Carbonara by cooking bacon, preparing an egg yolk and cheese mixture, cooking spaghetti, and combining these with pasta water to create a creamy sauce. The dish is humorously presented as 'not Carbonara' due to the use of bacon instead of guanciale and other non-traditional elements.

Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.

metadata.title: Not Spaghetti Carbonara - You Suck at Cooking (episode 138)

subtitles.text: You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.
It's so simple!
Today, hang out for a second, and you're gonna learn how to do it right.
Let's not waste any time, now let's go!
Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.
So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon.
And thickcut bacon would be best.
You could also use pancetta.
So I'll take about a half pound of bacon, and we're gonna slice this just pretty thick, this way.
That's about three quarters of an inch.
Turn this pan on to medium heat.
I'm doing a tiny bit of olive oil, I don't think it's traditional, but when I'm cooking Italian food, it just feels right.
Then go ahead and break your bacon into that pan, and what we're gonna do here is slowly render out the fat from this bacon, get it nice and crispy.
We'll use most of it in the pasta, and then we'll actually use some for garnish, because who doesn't like crispy bacon on top?
Now, bacon is rendering, pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water.
Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.
So first is very important, we need to talk about the cheese.
Here we have Pecorino Romano, it's a sheep's milk cheese, this one is aged.
I think this is what is traditionally used when you're making spaghetti carbonara, but as always, if you watch this channel, you know I love ParmigianoReggiano.
That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff.

So what I'm gonna do is a mixture of both these cheeses, and you want them to be pretty fine, so I'm gonna be using this cheese grater, and if you don't have one of those, just use this setting on a box grater, and just get to shredding.
I'm gonna do about three ounces of each of these cheeses, so half and half, but as always, with my videos, the full recipe is gonna be down in the description.
Underneath this video, you just gotta click that little arrow, and it'll open up.
So here's all our beautiful cheese.
Okay, now time for the eggs.

The way I see it, carbonara is already so rich, it doesn't need all egg yolks.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use thick-cut bacon for better texture. Ensure Parmigiano Reggiano is authentic by checking it is from Italy. Adjust pepper to personal taste.
tips_quotes: And thickcut bacon would be best.
That's not to be confused with Parmesan, make sure it says ParmigianoReggiano, and it's from Italy, and you'll know you have the good stuff.
Put as much pepper or as little pepper as you like, and whisk it in.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-3
subgoal_quotes: So we'll cook this spaghetti about 10 minutes in this pot, just slightly al dente, and then we'll finish it over in this baking pan.
materials_quotes: about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water.
So we'll cook this spaghetti about 10 minutes in this pot, just slightly al dente.
subgoal_summaries.outcome: Spaghetti cooked to slightly al dente, ready to be finished in the pan.
outcome_quotes: So we'll cook this spaghetti about 10 minutes in this pot, just slightly al dente, and then we'll finish it over in this baking pan.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: 1. Bring pasta water to a boil. 2. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the water. 3. Cook the spaghetti for about 10 minutes until slightly al dente. 4. Use tongs to transfer the spaghetti to the pan.
instructions_quotes: pasta water is coming up to a boil, and we're gonna season our pasta water just a little bit, about a tablespoon of salt, kosher salt, into about four quarts of water.
So we'll cook this spaghetti about 10 minutes in this pot, just slightly al dente.
We're just going to use our tongs here. Drop that in there.
subgoal_summaries.rationale: Less salt is added to the pasta water because carbonara has many salty elements.
rationale_quotes: Usually, I'm gonna put more salt, but because there's so many salty elements in carbonara, I wanna put less salt in the pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Leave the pasta water in the pot as it will be needed later.
tips_quotes: you want to leave this water in this pot. This will make sense in a minute.

metadata.title: Pasta Carbonara the American Way (With Bacon)

subtitles.text: Pasta, cream, bacon.
Cream?
Hi guys, we're gonna make spaghetti carbonara, a classic Italian dish.
Pasta, cheese, bacon.
What's not to love, right?
But it's really controversial.
I want to give you what I think is the most authentic recipe.
So first up guys, you only need five ingredients.
Guanciale.
This is the cured cheek of pork.
And as you can see, it's all about the fat.
It's salted, it's got pepper, it's dried and it's aged.
Of course, it's similar to smoked bacon and you can get some pretty good results actually.
But you can see this is quite lean.
So try and get them to not cut off the fat because you need it.
Or there's pancetta.
Then, most people use parmesan.
But actually, the more classic is pecorino romano.
Sheep's cheese.
It's crumbly, it's salty, freerange organic egg.
Pasta, black pepper and then optional, garlic.
So first up guys, grab the pasta by two hands.
Twist it into the water.
By twisting it, it won't stick together.
Put a tiny amount of salt in this water because the cheese and the guanciale is salty.
This beautiful pasta takes eight minutes to cook.
So I've got my guanciale.
I'm gonna remove the skin and I'm gonna take a nice centimetre slice of the guanciale.
Roughly chop this to about half centimetre chunks.
Now, the pan is cold.
Turn it on to a mediumhigh heat.
The reason I want it cold is because I want to render the fat out.
The guanciale goes in to the pan and this pan is getting hot.
Give the garlic a crack and then put it in the pan.
As this starts to sizzle, the fat will just pull out some of that perfume from the garlic.
Then there's the black pepper.
Get your peppercorns in a pestle and mortar.
Crack it.
Get a little sieve.
This is one of the most important little bits and no one really does it, okay.
Honestly, this is the outer skin.
This is much milder.
What we have here is the inside part, the peppercorn, which is hotter.
Perfect for a good hot carbonara.
The guanciale is getting golden.
Now, let's get on to the eggs.
Eggs are really, really delicate and if you don't treat these right, you end up with stirfried noodles and we don't want that.
I'm gonna take a bowl and I'm gonna crack the egg straight into there and I'm just gonna add a little pecorino to that.
So, like 20 grams.
Now, we're time sensitive so we're gonna have a little whisk up.
We've got dark guanciale.
We've got the fat that's come out of it and that's what you want.
You want attitude and colour.
Now, I'm gonna remove that garlic.
Turn the heat off and you're gonna drag the pasta and the water into the pan.
Use the water to stop the frying.
Bit of water, bit of water.
That water and the fat, that is what's going to emulsify to become a creamy sauce.
We're not frying anymore.
Can you hear that?
Quiet.
No frying at all.
Only then can we think about adding our egg.
As we toss, we add some more liquid.
That's the cream.
You get the cream through the emulsification of the cooking water and the fat and technique and timing.
So, as simple as this is, it's technical.
Get your friends, your family, get them around the table.
Glass of wine.
Look at that guys, look at that.
Carbonara and you finish with more pepper.
I'm so excited.
Spaghetti, carbonara with a beautiful little finishing of pecorino.
That is as classic as I can give you guys, from chefs, from nonnas.
It's about quality ingredients, the guanciale, the pecorino romana, quality eggs, the pepper, the technique of the pepper, good pasta and then the sensitivity of cooking it right.
Come on.
There's a little platter for two people and of course, the most important thing when you eat pasta is don't watch it, eat it.
Mmm.
That my friends, is a thing of joy.

I want to give you what I think is the most authentic recipe.

The dish is finished with black pepper and more pecorino cheese.

That water and the fat, that is what's going to emulsify to become a creamy sauce.
As we toss, we add some more liquid. That's the cream.

outcome_quotes: Look at that guys, look at that. Carbonara and you finish with more pepper.

subgoal_summaries.rationale: Starting with a cold pan allows the fat to render out slowly, enhancing the flavor. Cracking the peppercorns and sieving them ensures a hotter, more intense flavor, which is ideal for carbonara.
rationale_quotes: The reason I want it cold is because I want to render the fat out.
Honestly, this is the outer skin. This is much milder. What we have here is the inside part, the peppercorn, which is hotter. Perfect for a good hot carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a cold pan to start rendering the fat slowly. Sieve the cracked pepper to use the hotter inner part for a more intense flavor.
tips_quotes: The reason I want it cold is because I want to render the fat out.
This is one of the most important little bits and no one really does it, okay.

rationale_quotes: Eggs are really, really delicate and if you don't treat these right, you end up with stirfried noodles and we don't want that.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be time sensitive when whisking the eggs to ensure they are ready to be combined with the pasta at the right moment.

metadata.title: How to Make Classic Carbonara | Jamie Oliver

subtitles.text: I am Antonio Carluccio.
Welcome to my kitchen.
I show you how to make the real Carbonara.
Most of the people, they get it wrong, and I will show you why.
Now, this is boiling water to which we add in the ratio of 10 grams per liter of water, salt.
Has to be like this.
And immediately then, we put in, has to be boiling, a pasta.
In this case, it's sort of spaghettoni, the biggest size of spaghetti.
While this is cooking, it takes good 10 minutes, and no oil, please.
No oil, because you don't need it.
You just need to stir a little bit when it's in it, and that's it.
Now, for the original Carbonara, you need the guanciale, which is the cheek, the pork cheek.
And the Romans, they're very special in that because they do it, they cure it like ham, or like pancetta, and it's very tender, very tasty and tender.
Now, you have to cut it in chunks.
You can use naturally also pancetta, the normal pancetta, which is this one here.
But I like the guanciale when I have it, obviously.
And this is the recipe for two people.
Big chunks.
The Romans, they are mad for this pasta.
If there is a Roman pasta, it is this one here.
This is quite a lot for two people, let's see.
And the only thing you have to do now to make the sauce is to take good olive oil, put it in the pan.
There you are.
Put the guanciale into that, and this is the beginning of the sauce, and mostly also the end of it.
Because the rest is coming here into that bowl.
And now you take some good eggs, and for two people you take two eggs.
Oh, lovely colour, look at this.
To be a little bit naughty, I take just the yolk, and we beat it.
To this, you don't add any, any, any cream.
Absolutely forbidden.
So this is the beginning of the sauce.
So we put a little bit of parmesan.
In Roma, they use also pecorino cheese, which is a cheese to be grated.
There are fresh pecorino and aged pecorino.
But it's lovely to have a little bit of this.
Abundant pepper.
And another stir.
And this is the sauce.
I wouldn't put any salt here because the bacon here is quite salty, it's preserved.
We reduce it a little bit because I'm going to see what the pasta does.
I can see it is still stiff.
So I put it back again another three or four minutes.
Now here's the bacon that has produced also quite a lot of fat.
Should you be not wanting the fat, I show you a little trick.
Here we are.
And do this.
You absorb a little bit of the fat, and you take it off like this.
Very simple.
So the pasta seems to be doing well here, the taste now should be enough.
I switched off the guanciale because it's too hot and this is exactly what I don't want to be too hot.
So now I take the pasta and I put it into the, yes, that.
And you flavour it like this.
You let it cool down in doing this.
And it shouldn't be too hot because what is going to happen now should be the temperature enough to coat the egg around the pasta.
And now it comes, yes, the resistance, the actual sauce.
There you are.
And now we stir it like this.
You see usually by this stage the heat is so much in the wrong cooking that the eggs become scrambled eggs.
Not too scrambly.
And this is the carbonara.
And now the last touch, which is the embellishment.
Parmesan or pecorino, depending what you like.
And in my opinion also a nice touch of pepper.
This is decoration for me.
And this is the real carbonara.
The only one.
And it's exactly how it should be.
Creamy, without adding cream because this is the usual thing.
Like this is just fantastic.
Cameraman, everybody, you should taste it.
It's just wonderful.

meta_summary.title: $meta$
meta_summary.goal: The main purpose of the video is to demonstrate how to make authentic Pasta Carbonara, emphasizing the traditional method without common mistakes such as adding cream.
goal_quotes: I show you how to make the real Carbonara.
Most of the people, they get it wrong, and I will show you why.
meta_summary.procedure: The process begins with boiling salted water and cooking spaghettoni. While the pasta cooks, prepare the sauce by frying guanciale in olive oil. Separately, beat egg yolks with parmesan, pecorino, and pepper. Once the pasta is cooked, mix it with the guanciale and then combine with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs. Finish with additional cheese and pepper for garnish.
procedure_quotes: Now, this is boiling water to which we add in the ratio of 10 grams per liter of water, salt.
And immediately then, we put in, has to be boiling, a pasta.

And the only thing you have to do now to make the sauce is to take good olive oil, put it in the pan.
And now you take some good eggs, and for two people you take two eggs.
So we put a little bit of parmesan.
Abundant pepper.
So now I take the pasta and I put it into the, yes, that.
And now we stir it like this.
meta_summary.outcome: The final outcome is a creamy and authentic Pasta Carbonara, achieved without using cream, featuring a rich flavor from the guanciale, cheese, and pepper.

Creamy, without adding cream because this is the usual thing.

context.title: Combine Ingredients
context.text:
- **Parent Subgoal**: Combine Ingredients
	- **Outcome**: The pasta is coated with a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs, resulting in authentic Carbonara.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.definition: Gather all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including pasta (such as spaghetti or spaghettoni), eggs (using yolks or a combination of whole eggs and yolks), pecorino romano cheese, optionally Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, black pepper, and guanciale or bacon/pancetta as a substitute. Ensure all ingredients are fresh and ready for use. Optionally, prepare tools like a cheese grater and pepper grinder.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Pasta
subgoal_definitions.definition: Boil water in a large pot, add salt, and cook the pasta until it is al dente. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking. Reserve some pasta water before draining.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Meat
subgoal_definitions.definition: Cut the guanciale, pancetta, or bacon into small pieces. Cook it in a pan over medium heat until it is crispy and the fat is rendered. Optionally, start with a cold pan to render fat slowly. Remove from heat and let it cool slightly. Optionally, reserve some cooked meat for garnish.

subgoal_definitions.title: Mix Sauce
subgoal_definitions.definition: In a bowl, combine egg yolks (or a combination of whole eggs and yolks) with grated pecorino romano cheese and freshly ground black pepper. Mix until smooth. Optionally, add Parmigiano Reggiano cheese. Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.definition: Add the cooked pasta directly to the pan with the cooked meat. Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the pasta and meat, stirring quickly to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs. Use the residual heat to cook the eggs gently. Add more pasta water if needed to create a creamy sauce.

subgoal_definitions.title: Finish Dish
subgoal_definitions.definition: Plate the Pasta Carbonara, ensuring it is evenly coated with the sauce. Finish with additional grated cheese and black pepper to taste before serving. Optionally, add reserved crispy meat as garnish.

links.title: Guanciale Curing
links.description: The video explains that guanciale is cured like ham or pancetta, which makes it very tender and flavorful.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention the curing process of guanciale, while this video highlights that it is cured like ham or pancetta, emphasizing its tenderness and flavor.

links.title: Guanciale Tenderness
links.description: The video emphasizes that guanciale is very tender, which is a key characteristic for its use in Carbonara.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not specifically mention the tenderness of guanciale, while this video highlights its tenderness as a reason for its use in Carbonara.

links.title: Guanciale Flavor
links.description: The video highlights that guanciale is very tasty, which contributes to the flavor profile of Carbonara.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not specifically mention the flavor of guanciale, while this video highlights its taste as an important factor for its use in Carbonara.

links.title: Boiling Water Requirement
links.description: The video specifies that the water must be boiling before adding the pasta.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not specify the state of the water before adding the pasta, while this video emphasizes that the water must be boiling.

links.title: Salt Ratio
links.description: The video provides a specific ratio for adding salt to the water: 10 grams per liter.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video only mentioned adding a tiny amount of salt without specifying a ratio, while this video provides a precise measurement.

links.title: Spaghettoni Usage
links.description: The video specifies using spaghettoni, the biggest size of spaghetti, for the recipe.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not specify the type or size of pasta, while this video recommends using spaghettoni.

links.title: Cooking Time
links.description: The video states that the pasta should be cooked for about 10 minutes.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video mentioned cooking the pasta for eight minutes, while this video suggests a longer cooking time of 10 minutes.

links.title: Stirring Instruction
links.description: The video instructs to stir the pasta occasionally while it cooks.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention stirring the pasta, while this video includes it as part of the cooking process.

links.title: No Oil Rationale
links.description: The video advises against using oil in the pasta water, stating it is unnecessary.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention the use of oil, while this video explicitly advises against it.

links.title: Use Olive Oil
links.description: The video instructs to use good olive oil in the pan before adding the guanciale.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention using olive oil, while this video specifically instructs to add olive oil to the pan before cooking the guanciale.

links.title: Cut Big Chunks
links.description: The video instructs to cut the guanciale into big chunks before cooking.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video instructed to slice the guanciale into 1 cm slices and chop into 0.5 cm chunks, while this video suggests cutting it into big chunks.

links.title: Absorb Excess Fat
links.description: The video provides a tip to absorb excess fat with a paper towel if desired.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention managing excess fat, while this video offers a method to reduce fat by using a paper towel.

links.title: Turn Off Heat
links.description: The video advises turning off the heat to prevent the guanciale from becoming too hot.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention managing the heat after cooking, while this video suggests turning off the heat to avoid overheating the guanciale.

links.title: Use Pancetta Option
links.description: The video mentions that pancetta can be used as an alternative to guanciale.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video exclusively focused on using guanciale, while this video provides an alternative option of using pancetta.

links.title: Use Egg Yolks
links.description: The video instructs to use only egg yolks instead of whole eggs for the sauce, which contributes to a richer and creamier texture.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video used whole eggs, while this video specifies using only egg yolks for a richer sauce.

links.title: Add Parmesan Cheese
links.description: The video includes adding parmesan cheese to the egg mixture, in addition to pecorino cheese, to enhance the flavor of the sauce.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video only mentioned adding pecorino cheese, while this video includes both parmesan and pecorino cheeses.

links.title: Add Black Pepper
links.description: The video emphasizes adding abundant black pepper to the egg mixture to enhance the taste of the sauce.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention adding black pepper, while this video highlights its importance for flavor.

links.title: No Salt Needed
links.description: The video advises against adding salt to the sauce because the guanciale (or bacon) used in the recipe is already salty.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not address the saltiness of the guanciale, while this video specifically advises against adding extra salt.

links.title: No Cream Allowed
links.description: The video explicitly states that no cream should be added to the sauce to maintain the authenticity of the Carbonara recipe.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention the exclusion of cream, while this video emphasizes that adding cream is absolutely forbidden.

links.title: Stir to Combine
links.description: The video instructs to stir the egg yolks, cheeses, and pepper together to combine them into a sauce.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video mentioned whisking the mixture, while this video uses the term 'stir' to describe the process of combining the ingredients.

links.title: Cool Pasta Slightly
links.description: The video emphasizes letting the pasta cool slightly before adding the egg mixture to prevent the eggs from scrambling.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not mention the need to let the pasta cool slightly before adding the egg mixture, while this video highlights it as a crucial step to avoid scrambling the eggs.

links.title: Temperature Control
links.description: The video explains that the pasta should not be too hot when adding the egg mixture to ensure the eggs coat the pasta smoothly without scrambling.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not discuss the importance of controlling the pasta's temperature to prevent scrambling, while this video specifically addresses it as a key factor in achieving the desired texture.

links.title: Cheese Choice Flexibility
links.description: The video suggests using either Parmesan or pecorino cheese for the final touch, allowing for personal preference.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video specifically mentioned using pecorino cheese, while this video offers a choice between Parmesan or pecorino.

links.title: Emphasis on Authenticity
links.description: The video emphasizes that the dish is creamy without adding cream, highlighting the authenticity of the Carbonara.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not explicitly mention the absence of cream, while this video stresses the authenticity by pointing out that no cream is used.

links.title: Decoration Perspective
links.description: The video describes the final garnishing as a form of decoration, adding to the presentation of the dish.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video focused on enhancing flavor and presentation without specifically referring to it as decoration, while this video explicitly calls it decoration.

links.title: Salted Boiling Water
links.description: The video specifies the ratio of salt to water when boiling pasta, which is 10 grams per liter.
links.comparison: Such information is presented because the previous video did not specify the salt-to-water ratio for boiling pasta, while this video provides a precise measurement.

links.title: Using Spaghettoni
links.description: The video uses spaghettoni, a thicker type of spaghetti, for the Carbonara dish.
